Work Sans is a typeface family based loosely on early Grotesques, such as by Stephenson Blake , Miller & Richard and Bauerschen Giesserei . Grotesques fonts are among the earliest sans serif designs.

Grotesque fonts are typically characterized by low contrast and, although once considered rather plain, they now come in a dizzying array of weights and widths.

yl
es
Medium 500
Thin 100
Extra light 200
Light 300
Regular 400
Black 900
Bold 700
SemiBold 600
A

The fonts closer to the extreme weights are designed more for display use both on the web and in print. Overall, features are simplified and optimized for screen resolutions; for example, diacritic marks are larger than how they would be in print.

The Regular weight and others in the middle of the family are optimized for on-screen text usage at medium-sizes (14px-48px) and can also be used in print design.

All styles were updated to v1.40 to change the Thin (100) style to be the same as 'HairLine' in previous versions - even thinner! This avoids the complication of a second "Hairline" family.

Updated February 2020

Family has been upgraded to a variable font family.

Wei Huang is a Chinese-born Australian graphic and typeface designer known for creating the widely used open-source font, Work Sans. His work is influenced by the history of visual communication, vernacular typography, and subcultures. In 2014, Huang released Work Sans through Google Fonts, an award-winning open-source sans-serif font family inspired by early grotesques. It was optimized for on-screen use but is also versatile for print.
